facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 56 of 1959 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 56 of 1959. Appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 18, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1671 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated- December 18, 1957, of the former Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1671 of 1957,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated June 7, 1957 of Sessions Judge, Baroda in Criminal Appeal No. 33 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated June 7, 1957, of the Sessions Judge, Baroda, in Criminal Appeal No. 33 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 31, 1960 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.

facts.text: Respondent owned a milk shop within the Municipal limits of the city of Baroda.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent owned a milk shop within the Municipal limits of the city of Baroda.

facts.text: Food Inspector visited the shop on July 9, 1956 and purchased milk for analysis.

anchor.surface_text: The Food Inspector of the Municipality visited the shop on July 9, 1956 and purchased milk for analysis.

facts.text: Milk sample sent to Public Analyst; report stated sample was adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: This was sent to the Public Analyst and when his report was to the effect that the sample was adulterated,

facts.text: Inspector applied to Chief Officer, Borough Municipality, Baroda for consent to institute proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: the Inspector applied to the Chief Officer, Borough Municipality, Baroda, for the latters consent, for instituting criminal

facts.text: Chief Officer gave written consent to initiation of prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: A consent in writing to the initiation of this prosecution was given by the Chief Officer

facts.text: Complaint instituted charging respondent with offence under s.16 read with s.7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the complaint out of which this appeal arises was instituted charging the respondent with an offence under s. 16

facts.text: Case tried by Special Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Baroda.

anchor.surface_text: The case was tried by the Special Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Baroda.

facts.text: Accused denied guilt and raised technical objections including non-compliance with s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: Besides denying his guilt, the accused raised various technical objections, the principal of which was that the prosecution

facts.text: Magistrate overruled objections, held accused guilty, sentenced to fine Rs.300/- or 3 months RI.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate overruled these objections and holding the accused guilty of the offence charged sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 300/-

facts.text: Baroda Municipal Borough authorized Chief Officer and Health Officer by resolution No.222 dated May 7,1956 to grant sanction.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case Baroda Municipal Borough is the local authority and it has authorized the Chief Officer and the health officer

facts.text: Chief Officer gave consent in writing on October 13, 1956 at Ex.10/7.

anchor.surface_text: the Chief Officer has given consent in writing to lodge this complaint against the present accused under the Act on October 13, 1956.

facts.text: Sessions Judge set aside conviction and sentence on ground Food Inspector not competent under s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Court set aside the order of conviction and sentence on the ground that the Food Inspector was not competent

facts.text: Sessions Judge relied on Madras High Court decision in Cannanore Milk Supply Co-operative Society, In re (1956 2 M.L.J. 465).

anchor.surface_text: Relying on the decision of a single Judge of the Madras High Court in Cannanore Milk Supply Co-operative Society, In re

facts.text: Bombay High Court affirmed Sessions Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court affirmed the order passed by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: No dispute that Baroda Municipality authorized Chief Officer to grant consents under s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: There is here no dispute that the local authority the Baroda Municipality, had authorized the Chief Officer

facts.text: Chief Officer granted written consent on October 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute either that the Chief Officer granted on October 13, 1956, his written consent

facts.text: Consent given after considering Milk Analysis Report and other documents.

anchor.surface_text: This sanction is accorded after going through Milk Analysis Report and other pertinent documents and the nature of offence

facts.text: Resolution empowering Chief Officer at Ex.18/8.

anchor.surface_text: the copy of the Resolution of the Municipality empowering the Chief Officer and the health officer is also on record at Ex. 18/8.

facts.text: Respondent not represented before Supreme Court; amicus curiae appointed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was not represented before this Court, and in view of the importance of the matter, Mr. G. C. Mathur

facts.text: Supreme Court held prosecution instituted validly under s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, consider that the prosecution in the present case was instituted on a complaint which fulfilled the requirements
Criminal Appeal No. 56 of 1959. Appeal by special leave.
construction of s. 20 1  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 37 of 1954 .

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 20(1), Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
concepts.unlisted_description: No prosecution for an offence under this Act shall be instituted except by, or with the written consent of, the State Government or a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority.

anchor.surface_text: No prosecution for an offence under this Act shall be instituted except by, or with the written consent of, the State Government or a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 20(1), Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
concepts.unlisted_description: Quoted provision requiring written consent for prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: we entirely agree with the learned Judges of the High Court in their view that on the terms of s. 20 1  a prosecution could be instituted with the written consent not merely of the State Government but of a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority .

concepts.interpretation: Prosecution could be instituted with written consent not merely of State Government but also of local authority or person authorised thereby.

anchor.surface_text: The construction which has been put by the learned Sessions Judge obviously ignores the two commas, which appear in the section before and after the clause or with the written consent of . One of the commas precedes, and the other follows the clause or with the written consent of The plain grammatical meaning of this section is that the written consent may be of the State Government, or a local authority, or a person authorised in that behalf by the State Government or local authority.

concepts.interpretation: Plain grammatical meaning considering commas and structure; rejects construction ignoring punctuation.

issues.text: Whether on the terms of s. 20(1) a prosecution could be instituted with the written consent not merely of the State Government but of a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority

anchor.surface_text: we entirely agree with the learned Judges of the High Court in their view that on the terms of s. 20 1  a prosecution could be instituted with the written consent not merely of the State Government but of a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority .

holdings.text: we entirely agree with the learned Judges of the High Court in their view that on the terms of s. 20(1) a prosecution could be instituted with the written consent not merely of the State Government but of a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority

anchor.surface_text: we entirely agree with the learned Judges of the High Court in their view that on the terms of s. 20 1  a prosecution could be instituted with the written consent not merely of the State Government but of a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf by the State Government or a local authority .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain grammatical construction of s.20(1) considering commas and structure permits consent by State Government, local authority, or authorized person; rejects alternative requiring rewrite of statute.

holdings.text: the Statute does not in terms prescribe that the complainant shall be named in the written consent . The only question, therefore, is whether such a limitation or condition could be gathered as a necessary intendment of the provision [...] the further implication that the complainant must be named in the written consent does not, in our opinion, follow
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express textual requirement; purpose to prevent frivolous prosecutions satisfied by authority applying mind to facts (e.g., Analyst report); consent to prosecution, not to named person; different phrasing distinguishes classes.

holdings.text: We, therefore, consider that the prosecution in the present case was instituted on a complaint which fulfilled the requirements of s. 20(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, consider that the prosecution in the present case was instituted on a complaint which fulfilled the requirements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Local authority authorized Chief Officer by resolution; Chief Officer gave written consent after reviewing Analyst report and documents; consent valid without naming Food Inspector per s.20(1) interpretation.

holdings.text: the construction which found favour with the learned Judge of the Madras High Court in Cannanore Milk Supply Cooperative Society, In re is not possible without the sub-section being rewritten

anchor.surface_text: Even apart from the two commas, the construction which found favour with the learned Judge of the Madras High Court in Cannanore Milk Supply Cooperative Society, In re 1  is not possible without the sub-section being rewritten

holdings.reasoning_summary: Madras interpretation requires inserting 'by' before 'local authority,' altering statutory text impermissibly.

holdings.text: this apprehension is not justified, for the written consent has to be filed by the complainant in order to enable the complaint to be entertained
holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent filed with court, not public; no control issue even if name specified, as named person need not be municipal servant.
